title: 113_hr4565
content: The "Startup Capital Modernization Act of 2014" increases small issues exemptive authority under the Securities Act of 1933 to $10,000,000 and includes preemption of state laws. The amendment to the Securities Act of 1933 clarifies State enforcement authority regarding registration requirements and does not limit State actions against issuers or intermediaries using exemptions. It also clarifies State jurisdiction over unlawful conduct by intermediaries, issuers, and custodians. The amendment clarifies State enforcement authority over registration requirements and expands jurisdiction to include unlawful conduct by issuers or custodians in certain transactions. The amendment clarifies State enforcement authority over registration requirements and expands jurisdiction to include unlawful conduct by issuers or custodians in certain transactions. Additionally, it excludes certain entities from the shareholder cap. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to exclude securities issued under Regulation A from certain provisions if the issuer meets specific requirements. The Securities and Exchange Commission is required to issue a rule within 180 days to implement this amendment. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to exclude securities issued under Regulation A from certain provisions. Section 12(g)(7) of the Act applies to securities issued before, on, or after the enactment of this amendment. Section 12(g)(7) of the Act applies to securities issued before, on, or after the enactment of this amendment. SEC. 5. EXEMPTED TRANSACTIONS. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to exempt certain transactions meeting specific requirements, including transactions where each purchaser is an accredited investor and reasonable steps are taken to verify their status. The exemption provided by this subsection under the Securities Act of 1933 is not available for transactions involving certain parties such as issuers, underwriters, or dealers. Transactions meeting the requirements shall not be considered a distribution for regulatory purposes. The Securities Act of 1933 exemption does not apply to transactions involving specific parties like issuers, underwriters, or dealers. Transactions meeting the criteria are not considered distributions for regulatory purposes. The amendment includes redesignating subparagraphs and adding a new subparagraph related to section 4(a)(7).
